title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of access to credit spread globally, prompting the Federal Reserve to respond to the financial crisis. The financial crisis in 2008 led to a lack of credit access in the financial services industry, which spread globally. The Federal Reserve responded by setting a target range for the Federal funds rate at 0 to 0.25 percent to provide liquidity and stability to the financial markets. The Federal Reserve responded to the 2008 financial crisis by establishing a target range for the Federal funds rate at 0 to 0.25 percent, acknowledging the severity of the crisis and acting in response to unusual circumstances 11 times since the crisis began. The Federal Reserve has responded to the current crisis by exercising its authority to address "unusual and exigent circumstances" multiple times since the beginning of the financial crisis, with the last instance being in 1934. The Board of Governors extended assistance to nonmember institutions in efforts to address these circumstances. The Federal Reserve last addressed "unusual and exigent circumstances" in 1934. Recently, the Board of Governors extended assistance to nonmember institutions and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve took unprecedented actions to stabilize the economy. This included purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981 and establishing joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve established joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America, implementing the Term Asset-Backed Securities Lending Facility, and the Public-Private Partnership Investment Program. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed transparency commitment in 2009. Chairman Ben Bernanke reaffirmed the Federal Reserve's commitment to transparency in 2009 during his testimony to the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Comptroller General may conduct reviews, including onsite examinations, of credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal reserve bank, in carrying out actions approved by the Board under the Federal Reserve Act as the lender of last resort. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 allows the Board or any Federal reserve bank to establish credit facilities for providing temporary assistance to private institutions as the lender of last resort. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes the establishment of credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions as a lender of last resort, including facilities like the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, and the Primary Dealer Credit Facility. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes various credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions, including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, and Maiden Lane III, LLC. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes various credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions, including the Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, Maiden Lane III, LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, Reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes various credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions, including Maiden Lane III, LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles conducting lending activities. This authority will expire after a 5-year period from enactment. Government Sponsored Enterprise is a special purpose vehicle for credit facilities, with authority expiring after 5 years from enactment. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative action. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative action, including a detailed description of the findings and conclusions with recommendations for appropriate action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records.--Section 714(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to grant the Comptroller General access to officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility established by an agency upon request. The Comptroller General can make and retain copies of records as needed. The Comptroller General may request access to records from officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility. The Comptroller General can make and retain copies of records as deemed appropriate. Amendments allow for access to copies of records and credit facilities established by an agency.
